channel.title: Memory Grain Blog
channel.description: Deep dives into the Open Memory Specification (.mg format) — COSE signing, header bytes, GDPR compliance, autonomous vehicles, IoT device profiles, and portability.

item.title: OMS for Autonomous Vehicles: Structured Memory for Sensor Fusion, Decisions, and Audit
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification maps to autonomous vehicle systems — from LiDAR and camera observations with sync groups and coordinate frames to navigation goals, actuator commands, and device profiles for edge-to-cloud processing.

item.title: Agent Memory for Customer Service: How OMS Captures, Structures, and Ports Support Knowledge
item.description: Customer service AI agents lose context between sessions, across channels, and when switching platforms. The Open Memory Specification provides a structured memory model — Episodes for raw transcripts, Facts for customer knowledge, Goals for issue tracking, Workflows for escalation — with GDPR-ready PII handling and cross-platform portability via .mg files.

item.title: OMS for Education and Research: Knowledge Graphs, Citations, and Reproducibility
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification maps to education and research — using Facts as knowledge graph triples, provenance chains as citation trails, Episodes for student interactions, Goals for learning objectives, embedding refs for semantic search, and content addressing for reproducible research.

item.title: OMS for Financial Services: Audit-Ready Agent Memory for Trading, Compliance, and Risk
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification maps to financial services — from trading signals and order execution to SOX-compliant audit trails, bi-temporal decision reconstruction, COSE-signed trade records, and regulatory compliance tags for PCI-DSS, Basel III, and Sarbanes-Oxley.

item.title: OMS for Healthcare: HIPAA-Compliant Agent Memory for Patient Data
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification maps to healthcare AI — from patient observations and diagnoses to treatment plans, with PHI protection, HIPAA compliance mapping, per-patient encryption, selective disclosure, and bi-temporal queries for clinical audit.

item.title: Agent Memory for Legal Technology: Tamper-Proof Records, Discovery, and Chain of Custody with OMS
item.description: Legal AI agents must maintain tamper-proof records, support discovery, handle attorney-client privilege, and preserve chain of custody. The Open Memory Specification maps to these requirements through immutable grains, COSE signatures for authentication, selective disclosure for privilege, grain protection for litigation holds, and .mg files as evidence packages.

item.title: Agent Memory for Manufacturing and Industrial IoT: Sensors, Predictive Maintenance, and Edge Intelligence
item.description: Factories generate thousands of sensor readings per second. The Open Memory Specification maps this data to Observations for sensor telemetry, Facts for equipment knowledge, Workflows for learned SOPs, and Checkpoints for shift handoff — with device profiles from 512-byte microcontrollers to cloud-scale analytics.

item.title: OMS for Robotics: Multi-Sensor Fusion, Spatial Context, and Mission Recovery
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification maps to robotics systems — using Observation grains for multi-sensor fusion with coordinate frames and sync groups, Goal hierarchies for task decomposition, Checkpoints for state recovery, Workflows for manipulation skills, and device profiles from embedded MCUs to cloud planners.

item.title: Anatomy of a .mg Blob
item.description: A byte-by-byte walkthrough of the 9-byte fixed header and MessagePack payload that make up a memory grain binary blob, using the actual hex from OMS Test Vector 1.

item.title: Auditable AI Provenance: Cross-Links and Derivation Trails in OMS
item.description: How Section 14 of the Open Memory Specification enables full audit trails through provenance chains and typed cross-links — the derivation trail every grain carries, the closed vocabulary of 11 relation types, the critical normative note on 'replaces', and how grains form knowledge graphs with typed edges.

item.title: Bi-Temporal Modeling in OMS: Five Timestamps, Full History
item.description: OMS gives every memory grain five timestamps spanning two independent time axes — event time and system time. This bi-temporal model enables precise auditing, point-in-time reconstruction, and regulatory compliance without sacrificing immutability.

item.title: Building Your First OMS Implementation: A Practical Guide
item.description: A step-by-step guide to implementing the Open Memory Specification, from Level 1 Minimal Reader through Level 3 Production Store — with test vectors, library recommendations, and common pitfalls to avoid.

item.title: Content Addressing with SHA-256: How Memory Grains Get Their Identity
item.description: A deep dive into how OMS uses SHA-256 content addressing to give every memory grain a unique, verifiable, tamper-evident identity — covering the formula, the five roles of a content address, temporal uniqueness, and security considerations.

item.title: Deterministic Serialization: How OMS Guarantees Identical Bytes
item.description: A deep dive into the canonical serialization rules in Section 4 of the Open Memory Specification — key ordering, integer encoding, float constraints, NFC normalization, and the full 10-step algorithm that ensures two independent implementations always produce the same bytes.

item.title: Device Profiles: Running OMS from Cloud Servers to Microcontrollers
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification's three device profiles — Extended, Standard, and Lightweight — adapt the .mg format for everything from cloud servers with gigabytes of RAM to battery-powered microcontrollers with kilobytes.

item.title: Field Compaction: Shrinking Grains Without Losing Meaning
item.description: How OMS maps human-readable field names to compact short keys for efficient binary storage — a complete guide to Section 6 of the Open Memory Specification, covering core fields, type-specific fields, compaction rules, and nested compaction boundaries.

item.title: GDPR-Ready Agent Memory: Per-User Encryption, Crypto-Erasure, and Compliance Mapping
item.description: How the Open Memory Specification addresses GDPR, CCPA, and HIPAA requirements through per-user encryption with HKDF-SHA256, crypto-erasure via key destruction, blind index lookups, and built-in compliance primitives mapped to specific regulatory articles.

item.title: Grain Protection: How Invalidation Policy Safeguards Critical Knowledge
item.description: A comprehensive guide to Section 23 of the Open Memory Specification — the invalidation_policy field that declares who can remove a grain from trusted status. Covers all six protection modes, fail-closed semantics, goal laundering attacks, scope propagation, bypass path closures, and key separation requirements.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: Checkpoints
item.description: Checkpoints are agent state snapshots for save/restore in OMS — like a video game save point for AI agents. Learn about the Checkpoint memory type, its context map, plan and history fields, fault tolerance patterns, and the immutability model.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: Episodes
item.description: Episodes are the raw, unstructured interaction records in OMS — the input to consolidation that extracts structured Facts. Learn about the Episode memory type, its fields, the consolidation pipeline, and real-world use cases.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: Facts
item.description: A comprehensive guide to the Fact memory type in OMS — the semantic triple model, required and optional fields, confidence scoring, bi-temporal validity, protected facts, consolidation levels, and real-world applications.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: Goal — Lifecycle Semantics for Agent Objectives
item.description: The most complex OMS memory type: Goal grains model explicit objectives with state machines, structured criteria, delegation, hierarchies, and protection against goal laundering.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: Observation — Sensor Readings, Cognitive Percepts, and Environmental Measurements
item.description: How OMS Observation grains capture high-volume data from physical sensors, AI cognitive agents, and human observers — with spatial context, temporal alignment, and multi-modal content references.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: ToolCall — The Immutable Audit Trail for Agent Actions
item.description: How OMS ToolCall grains record every tool invocation, argument, and result as an immutable, content-addressed record — enabling replay, debugging, cost tracking, and compliance.

item.title: Memory Type Deep Dive: Workflows
item.description: Workflows are procedural memory in OMS — learned sequences of actions that agents can replay. Learn about the Workflow memory type, the trigger-steps model, how agents learn workflows, versioning through supersession, and industry use cases.

item.title: MessagePack vs. CBOR: Choosing an Encoding for OMS Grains
item.description: A technical comparison of the two encoding options in the Open Memory Specification — MessagePack (default) and CBOR (optional) — covering deterministic rules, key sorting differences, float encoding, content address implications, and when to use each.

item.title: The .mg File Format: One File, Full Memory
item.description: Section 11 of the OMS spec defines the .mg container — a portable binary file that packages any number of memory grains with a 16-byte header, random-access index, optional compression, and a SHA-256 footer checksum. This is how agent memory gets exported, shared, and archived.

item.title: Migrating to OMS: A Practical Guide
item.description: A step-by-step guide for migrating existing agent memory systems to the Open Memory Specification — mapping proprietary stores to OMS grain types, defining a namespace strategy, adopting conformance levels incrementally, and using the .mg file as the universal export format.

item.title: Multi-Modal Memory: How OMS References Images, Audio, Video, and Embeddings
item.description: A complete guide to Section 7 of the Open Memory Specification — content references, embedding references, modality-specific metadata, and the security model for linking grains to external multi-modal content without embedding blobs.

item.title: The Case for an Open Memory Standard
item.description: Why agent memory locked in proprietary formats is a liability, how the Open Memory Specification's eight requirements and ten design principles solve the portability problem, and what OMS intentionally leaves out of scope.

item.title: Selective Disclosure: Field-Level Privacy for Memory Grains
item.description: OMS lets you prove a fact exists without revealing its sensitive fields. Inspired by SD-JWT (RFC 9901), selective disclosure replaces chosen values with SHA-256 hashes — enabling GDPR-compliant sharing, inter-company collaboration, and court-admissible redaction at the grain level.

item.title: Sensitivity Classification: Routing PII and PHI at the Header Level
item.description: How the OMS v1.0 sensitivity classification system uses 2-bit header fields and structured tag vocabularies to enable O(1) routing of personally identifiable information and protected health information to appropriate storage tiers --- without deserializing the payload.

item.title: Signing Memory Grains: COSE Envelopes and Decentralized Identity
item.description: OMS uses COSE Sign1 envelopes and W3C Decentralized Identifiers to provide cryptographic authenticity for memory grains — without certificate authorities, without centralized PKI, and without changing a grain's content address.

item.title: What Is a Memory Grain?
item.description: The memory grain is the atomic unit of agent knowledge in the Open Memory Specification. This post covers the seven memory types, the immutability model, content addressing, the .mg container capabilities, and the ten design principles that shape the format.

item.title: Why AI Agents Need Persistent Memory
item.description: LLM context windows are not memory. Production agents need portable, verifiable, immutable knowledge that survives restarts, transfers between systems, and stands up to audit. Here is what persistent memory requires and why the Open Memory Specification exists.
